refnamediv.refpurpose: arrays for multidimensional function evaluation on grid

refsynopsisdiv.title: Calling Sequence
refsynopsisdiv.synopsis: [X, Y] = ndgrid(x,y) [X, Y, Z] = ndgrid(x,y,z) [X, Y, Z, T] = ndgrid(x,y,z,t) [X1, X2, ..., Xm] = ndgrid(x1,x2,...,xm)

listitem.para: matrices in case of 2 input arguments, or else hypermatrices

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This is an utility routine useful to create arrays for function evaluation on 2, 3, ..., n dimensional grids. For instance in 2d, a grid is defined by two vectors, x and y of length nx and ny, and you want to evaluate a function (says f) on all the grid points, that is on all the points of coordinates (x(i),y(j)) with i=1,..,nx and j=1,..,ny. In this case, this function can compute the two matrices X,Y of size nx x ny such that :
refsection.programlisting: X(i,j) = x(i) for all i in [1,nx] Y(i,j) = y(j) and j in [1,ny]
refsection.para: and the evaluation may be done with Z=f(X,Y) (at the condition that you have coded f for evaluation on vector arguments, which is done (in general) by using the element-wise operators .*, ./ and .^ in place of *, / and ^).
In the 3d case, considering 3 vectors x,y,z of length nx, ny and nz, X,Y,Z are 3 hypermatrices of size nx x ny x nz such that :
refsection.programlisting: X(i,j,k) = x(i) Y(i,j,k) = y(j) for all (i,j,k) in [1,nx]x[1,ny]x[1,nz] Z(i,j,k) = z(k)
refsection.para: In the general case of m input arguments x1, x2, .., xm, then the m output arguments X1, X2, .., Xm are hypermatrices of size nx1 x nx2 x ... x nxm and :
